IIA 14-52507
Winnacker

The Human Frontier Science Program (HFSP) is an international partnership aimed at promoting basic research on the complex mechanisms of living organisms. The current members are the original G-7 members plus Switzerland, Norway, the European Union, South Korea, Australia, India and New Zealand. Japan and the United States are the principal financial contributors. The U.S. continues to be the primary beneficiary of the program with a disproportionate amount of both Fellows and grantees coming to the U.S.

HFSP, headquartered in Strasbourg, France, provides support through peer-reviewed postdoctoral, early career, and cross-disciplinary fellowships and collaborative research grants. Postdoctoral fellowships are available for research in foreign laboratories and career development awards are offered for repatriating HFSP fellows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Human Frontier Science Program (HFSP) is an international program that funds frontier research in the life sciences. The support extends across continental boundaries and scientific disciplines with a strong focus on basic research that addresses complex mechanisms of living organisms and systems. There are currently 15 members that provide the annual budget of the program: Australia, Canada, France, Germany, India, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Norway, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and the European Union. The National Science Foundation (NSF) represents the USA in the Program together with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and their combined contribution amounts to 10,129 million USD. Academic research institutions in the US are by far the biggest beneficiary of HFSP funding thus providing for a positive return on the US investment in this program.

 HFSP’s funding programs play a unique role in fostering transformative frontier research in international scientific collaborations and they complement the national research missions of each country by funding “science without borders” that is entirely investigator driven. HFSP research grants support international teams of scientists collaborating in a joint project. The fellowship and Career Development Award are geared towards supporting postdoctoral researchers for working abroad and to support their next career step.

The HFSP grant program promotes innovative approaches to basic biological research ranging from molecular studies to systems neuroscience and including many of the areas of interest to NSF. Due to decreased funding opportunities in the MSPs, the number of initial applications rose sharply to 1013, particularly from mid to late career scientists, whose projects swelled the senior Program Grant program (82% of the total) but in many cases were disappointing being out of scope or a continuation of existing rather than novel collaborations. Following three rounds of extensive reviews a total of 31 research grants were proposed for funding though 35 merited support. Teams of Young Investigators represented 30% of the awards (from 18% of the applications). The grant program engages scientists from all over the world. For this award period there were 98 scientists in the teams funded by the grant program out of which 18 scientists are based in the US.

The HFSP fellowship program creates international opportunities for research, prioritizing support to applicants who broaden their fields or switch expertise and in so doing prepare themselves for a career in frontier research. The number of applications was exceptionally high (788) but only 75 awards could be attributed. The program attracted applications from 61 nationalities. In terms of host country, aggregate data for the period 2005-2012 shows that 52% of applicants and 62% of awardees select host laboratories in the USA. In 2013-2015, this gap widened to 47% of applicants and 63% of awards, indicating the strength of applications to work in the USA but also an increase in proposals to a range of other countries.

The aim of the Career Development Award (CDA) is to support former HFSP fellows in the transition to independence and to stimulate frontier research among young researchers. Submission is limited to HFSP fellows and therefore it is not surprising that the quality of the proposals is exceptionally high. 63 applications were received, of which 8 were recommended for funding (13% success rate cf. 21% last year). Most awardees use the program as a mechanism for repatriation even though CDA holders may move to any MSP since 2012.
